tags: java, spring, spring-cloud, spring-cloud-gateway, api-gateway, gateway
excerpt:
In this post, we will go to steps to create an API gateway using Spring Cloud Stack

Table of contents

content:
In this post, we will go to steps to create an API gateway using Spring Cloud Stack

Table of contents

  • What is API Gateway?
  • What is Spring Cloud Gateway?
  • Building discovery server
  • Building question service
  • Configure the question service
    • Question model
    • Create question repository
    • Initialize some data
    • Create question controller
  • Building an API gateway
    • Configure name and port for the gateway
    • OPTION 1: Configure application.properties or application.yml
    • OPTION 2: Configure a RouteLocator
  • Test the gateway

What is API Gateway?

When building microservices, you don’t want every client has to know all of your services. If the client knows about each service, it will come with many drawbacks:

  • Composition logic will reside in the clients
  • Clients have to control collaboration between services
  • Each service doesn’t have the flexibility to change its API because it would break the clients if the change in the API happens
  • Services will not have encapsulation. Because when you merge or split services, it will impact the clients as well

So it is better to have a service that works as a gateway that encapsulates other services and clients only need to know one service to talk to.

What is Spring Cloud Gateway?

If you are building microservices using Java and Spring technologies and want to build an API gateway for use by mobile clients or front end apps. Spring Cloud Gateway is a great library to start with.

It is built on top of Spring MVC. It provides a simple and effective way to route to APIs.

Building discovery server

Go to https://start.spring.io/ and select Eureka Server.

Eureka Server will help you manage services and its instances.

Name it as eureka-service and hit generate project

In the EurekaServiceApplication file, add the annotation @EnableEurekaServer for spring boot to know it is a discovery server

@SpringBootApplication
@EnableEurekaServer
public class EurekaServiceApplication {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		SpringApplication.run(EurekaServiceApplication.class, args);
	}
}

In the file application.properties, add these configurations

server.port=8761
eureka.client.fetch-registry=false
eureka.client.register-with-eureka=false
  • server.port=8761: to tell Spring Boot server run in port 8761
  • The flowing next lines fetch-registry and register-with-eureka is set to false because it is a eureka server so it doesn’t need to fetch or register with itself

And start the eureka-service

Building question service

Secondly, we will build a question service, this service will be routed by the API gateway

Go to https://start.spring.io/ and select these dependencies

In this service, we will use reactive web and reactive mongodb. If you don’t familiar with reactive programming, you can refer to this article https://spring.io/blog/2016/06/07/notes-on-reactive-programming-part-i-the-reactive-landscape

Eureka Discovery it is a eureka client that will connect to Eureka server that we’ve already built above.

Actuator helps you manage and monitor your application.

Lombok is a library will help you generate getters, setters, toString, and many other useful things. You can refer to this quick Lombok guide Guide to lombok

Name it as question-service and hit generate project

Configure the question service

Open the file application.properties and add the name for the question service

spring.application.name=question-service

The name will help other services can request the question service

Question model

@Data
@AllArgsConstructor
@NoArgsConstructor
@Document
public class Question {
    @Id
    private String id;
    private String name;
    private long score;
}

Question class will be annotated as document (@Document) in mongodb.

Lombok is used to reduce boilerplate code like getters, setters, toString, constructors, etc.

Create question repository

public interface QuestionRepository extends ReactiveMongoRepository<Question, String> {
}

We will use reactive mongo in this project

Initialize some data

@Component
@Slf4j
public class Initializer implements ApplicationRunner {

    private final QuestionRepository questionRepo;

    public Initializer(QuestionRepository questionRepo) {
        this.questionRepo = questionRepo;
    }

    @Override
    public void run(ApplicationArguments args) throws Exception {
        questionRepo.deleteAll()
                .thenMany(Flux.just("q1", "q2", "q3", "q4", "q5"))
                .map(name -> new Question(null, name, ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(1, 100)))
                .flatMap(questionRepo::save)
                .thenMany(questionRepo.findAll())
                .subscribe(q -> log.info("Created: " + q));
    }
}

Initializer class is a component (@Component) that implements run method from ApplicationRunner, so at the starting of the question service, the run method will be called automatically.

In the run method, we are going to create some sample questions.

Create question controller

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/questions")
public class QuestionController {

    private final QuestionRepository questionRepo;

    public QuestionController(QuestionRepository questionRepo) {
        this.questionRepo = questionRepo;
    }

    @GetMapping
    public Flux<Question> findAll() {
        return questionRepo.findAll();
    }

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public Mono<Question> findById(@PathVariable String id) {
        return questionRepo.findById(id);
    }
}

QuestionController will provide two simple endpoints: get all questions, and get question by id.

Building an API gateway

Go to https://start.spring.io/ and select these dependencies

We need a gateway, reactive web, Eureka client and actuator for the API gateway

Name it as gateway and hit generate project

Configure name and port for the gateway

Open the file application.properties and add the name for the gateway

spring.application.name=gateway
server.port=8081

Now we have two options to route traffic from the gateway to other services

OPTION 1: Configure application.properties or application.yml

Add these lines to application.properties

# OPTION 1
spring.cloud.gateway.discovery.locator.enabled=true
spring.cloud.gateway.discovery.locator.lower-case-service-id=true

This configuration will enable discovery locator and make sure that service names (spring.application.name) are lower case

OPTION 2: Configure a RouteLocator

Comment or remove property configurations if you added in option 1

Create a file called RouteConfig.java

@Configuration
public class RouteConfig {

    //  OPTION 2
    @Bean
    public RouteLocator routeLocator(RouteLocatorBuilder builder) {
        return builder.routes()
                .route(r ->
                        r.path("/questions")
                                .uri("lb://question-service/questions")
                )
                .build();
    }
}

RouteConfig is a @Configuration class, it has RouteLocator that route paths follow patterns to a destination. For example:

  • If the path match /questions, go to /question-service/questions

If the uri has lb scheme, the LoadBalancerClient will be called to resolve question-service to an actual host and port and replace the URI.

Test the gateway

  1. Check eureka server: Go to http://localhost:8761, you should see question-service and gateway

  2. With option 1: In the browser, go to http://localhost:8081/question-service/questions

  3. With option 2: Goto http://localhost:8081/questions

That’s it! It’s all you need to set up a simple API gateway. In the later posts, I will add more example for the API gateway.

You can find the sample code at Github repo

title: Recover Postgres password when forgetting it in Centos
excerpt:
Have you ever forget Postgres password after a long time installed it?

In this post, we will go through steps to recover your Postgres password in Centos (Linux environment)

1. ...
content:
Have you ever forget Postgres password after a long time installed it?

In this post, we will go through steps to recover your Postgres password in Centos (Linux environment)

1. Login with Postgres user

sudo su - postgres

You will be asked to enter your password or enter new password

2. Open the file /var/lib/pgsql/9.6/data/pg_hba.conf

Or /var/lib/pgsql/<YOUR_VERSION>/data/pg_hba.conf

Change the line

local all all md5

to

local all all trust

Remember to change it back to md5 later

3. Restart the Postgres server

service postgresql-9.6.service restart

Change the number 9.6 to your postgres version

4. Change postgres password

psql -U postgres

It will not asked your password

Type \password to change the password. And then type \q to exit

5. Then go back to /var/lib/pgsql/9.6/data/pg_hba.conf

And change back the line

local all all trust

To

local all all md5

6. Restart the Postgres server again

service postgresql-9.6.service restart

Change the number 9.6 to your postgres version

7. Finally

Type psql -U postgres and enter your new password

That’s it! That all you need to do to recover your postgres password

title: Sending email using Spring Boot
excerpt:
In this post, we will go to steps to configure sending email using Spring Boot and Gmail as the mail provider

You can find the sample code at repo:
content:
In this post, we will go to steps to configure sending email using Spring Boot and Gmail as the mail provider

You can find the sample code at repo: Demo email

Table of contents

  • Table of contents
  • Getting started
  • Configure application.properties
  • Let’s create a email service to send simple messages
  • Let’s test the EmailService
  • Conclusions

Getting started

  1. The first thing you need to do is allow Gmail to send emails from your app.

    Go to https://myaccount.google.com/lesssecureapps

    Please aware the security you are changing in this account

  2. Go to https://start.spring.io to create the Spring Boot project, we only need Mail dependency for now. And hit generate

Configure application.properties

Open file application.properties and add these configurations:

spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.connectiontimeout=10000
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.timeout=5000
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.writetimeout=10000
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.auth=true
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.starttls.enable=true
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.ssl.trust=smtp.gmail.com
spring.mail.host=smtp.gmail.com
spring.mail.port=587
spring.mail.username=<YOUR_GMAIL_USERNAME>
spring.mail.password=<YOUR_GMAIL_PASSWORD>

Let’s create a email service to send simple messages

import org.springframework.mail.SimpleMailMessage;
import org.springframework.mail.javamail.JavaMailSender;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;

@Service
class EmailService {

    private final JavaMailSender mailSender;

    EmailService(JavaMailSender mailSender) {
        this.mailSender = mailSender;
    }

    public void sendSimpleMessage(String to, String subject, String text) {
        SimpleMailMessage message = new SimpleMailMessage();

        message.setTo(to);
        message.setSubject(subject);
        message.setText(text);

        mailSender.send(message);
    }
}

The EmailService is a component managed by Spring container through annotation @Service

Let’s test the EmailService

I create an Initializer class that extends from CommandLineRunner. It uses EmailService to send a simple email.

For example:

@Component
class Initializer implements CommandLineRunner {

    private final EmailService emailService;

    Initializer(EmailService emailService) {
        this.emailService = emailService;
    }

    @Override
    public void run(String... args) throws Exception {
        emailService.sendSimpleMessage("vndung147@gmail.com", "Hello", "Just to say hi!!!");
    }
}

Conclusions

That’s it.

It is just a simple post to configure and send a simple email.

In the next post, I will demonstrate how to use Mail with Thymeleaf to send a email with a specified template.

You can find the sample code at Github repo

title: Seperate of concerns with Spring events and AOP
excerpt: Suppose that you want components in your system are loosely coupled. The results or actions of one component does not effect the others. For example, the component used for creating a user does not have any interventions with the component ...
content:
Suppose that you want components in your system are loosely coupled. The results or actions of one component does not effect the others. For example, the component used for creating a user does not have any interventions with the component used for sending user activation email.

In that case you can use Spring event and Spring AOP to solve the problem. Let’s see how it works in this post

You can find the sample code at repo: https://github.com/dungvokms/demo-events-and-aop

Table of contents

  • Table of contents
  • Getting started
  • Using Spring events
  • Using Spring AOP
  • Conclusions

Getting started

In this example, we will go though an example of creating a user and we will send an email to the user to activate the account. Obviously, we will have two services UserService and EmailService. Let’s look at the example code:

UserService.java

public User createUser(UserInfo userInfo) {
    User user = info.toUser();

    // validate userInfo
    // save the user info to the database

    emailService.sendActivationEmail(userInfo);
}

You can run the demo code at Github repo and the output is:

>> Created user 5b420351-f419-4e2e-b5c9-d97eb3ba86ad
>> Send email to user vnd@mail.com

In that case, you are creating coupling between UserService and EmailService. The UserService has to know about EmailService and calls send email after the user is created successfully. And when the EmailService changes its interface the UserService have to change too.

Using Spring events

To make it more loosely coupled, you can use event to solve this problem

After saving the user info into the database, UserService will publish a user created event and anyone who is interested in that event can process the next step after user created. So the code will look something like this:

UserService.java

public User createUser(UserInfo userInfo) {
    // validate userInfo

    // save the user info to the database

    eventPublisher.publishEvent(new UserCreatedEvent(this, user));
}

After the user is created, the event publisher will be called to publish a UserCreatedEvent to notify all the listeners a new user is just created

EmailService.java is a listener who is interested in UserCreatedEvent

public class EmailService {

    @EventListener(UserCreatedEvent.class)
    public handleUserCreatedEvent(UserCreatedEvent event) {
        this.send(event.getObject));
    }

    public void send(User user) {
        // send an email to user to activate the account
    }
}

The EmailService is always listen on the UserCreatedEvent and when someone publish that event (in this case is UserService) it will catch the event, retrieve the user from the event and send an email to that user to activate the account he/she just created

At this step, you can stop at it, but if you want your business logic of creating a user don’t mix with any other logic like sending an email. And you might also notice that the publish event logic is not belongs to the create user logic

public User createUser(UserInfo userInfo) {
    // validate userInfo
    // save the user info to the database

    // ==> not belongs to user creating logic
    eventPublisher.publishEvent(new UserCreatedEvent(this, user));       
}

Using Spring AOP

So you can seperate it further by using Spring AOP. Aspect-Oriented Programming (AOP) enables modularization of cross-cutting concerns. For example, for logging you don’t need to have a log at every method, you can use AOP to centralize the logging logic in one place.

To apply it the first one is to create an annotation to mark this method that it needs to send an event after it returns successfully

public @interface EmailAfterReturning {
}

Create an handler class to handle @EmailAfterReturning annotation

@Aspect
@Component
public class EmailAnnotationHandler {

    private final EmailService emailService;

    public EmailAnnotationHandler(EmailService emailService) {
        this.emailService = emailService;
    }

    @AfterReturning(value = "@annotation(EmailAfterReturning)", returning = "retVal")
    public void handleSendingEmail(JoinPoint jp, Object retVal) {
        emailService.sendActivationEmail((User) retVal);
    }
}

When having email annotation, you can use it to send an email after successfully creating an user:

@EmailAfterReturning
public User createUser(UserInfo userInfo) {
    // validate userInfo
    // save the user info to the database
}

After your new user is created successfully, an email will be send automatically. If an exception is thrown in the user creating logic code, there is no email will be sent.

The demo code for AOP is at Github repo

Conclusions

So you can remove the coupling between the sending email logic and creating user logic. And the concerns of creating user and sending email is seperated.

You can find the sample code at Github repo

title: Guide to lombok
excerpt:
Have you ever heard Lombok?

If you’ve worked in Java projects that have too many getters/setters and/or boilerplate code.

Lombok is a great library to reduce boilerplate code in your project
content:
Have you ever heard Lombok?

If you’ve worked in Java projects that have too many getters/setters and/or boilerplate code.

Lombok is a great library to reduce boilerplate code in your project

Table of contents

  • Table of contents
  • How to start with it?
  • [1] Val, var
  • [2] Getter/Setter
  • [3] Cleanup
  • [4] Constructors
    • @NoArgsConstructor
    • @RequiredArgsConstructor
    • @AllArgsConstructor
  • [5] Data
  • [6] Log
  • Others

How to start with it?

  1. A maven dependency (I will use Maven in this post, you can use Gradle as well)

     <dependency>
     <groupId>org.projectlombok</groupId>
     <artifactId>lombok</artifactId>
     <version>1.18.2</version>
     <scope>provided</scope>
 </dependency>

  2. Lombok plugin in your IDE

[1] Val, var

If you know Kotlin, it is the same as val and var in Kotlin

Java 10 also have the Local-Variable Type Inference with var

Use val for final local variables (variables that are not changeable)

import lombok.val;

val a = 10; // a is now int
 
a = 11; // error, not changeable

Use var for local variable ((variables that are changeable)

import lombok.var;

var b = "Hello";
b = "Hello there"; // valid
 
// type is inferred
System.out.println(b.getClass().getSimpleName()); // ==> String

[2] Getter/Setter

If you find that creating setters/getters is tedious and make the useless code

Then Lombok can help you with that through @Getter and @Setter

public class Customer {
    private Long id;
    private String name;
 
    public Long getId() { return id; }
    public void setId(Long id) { this.id = id; }
    public String getName() { return name; } 
    public void setName(String name) { this.name = name; }
}

Can be replaced with

public class Customer {
 
    @Getter
    @Setter
    private Long id;
 
    @Getter
    @Setter
    private String name;
 
    // no longer setters and getters
}

The example is just two fields, but in practice a class can probably contain 20 fields so using Lombok can help us a lot

[3] Cleanup

Have you ever create InputStream/OutputStream and forgot to close them

Or you get annoyed with try/catch/finally block to close them

String greeting = "Hello";
InputStream is = null;
OutputStream os = null;
 
try {
    is = new ByteArrayInputStream(greeting.getBytes());
    os = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
 
    while (true) {
        int val = is.read();
        if (val == -1) {
            break;
        }
        os.write(val);
    }
 
    System.out.println(os.toString());  // Hello
 
} finally {
    if (is != null) {
        is.close();
    }
    if (os != null) {
        os.close();
    }
}

Lombok can call .close() method for you at the end of the scope you are in

Or whatever method name you’ve specified in @Cleanup. For example @Cleanup("dispose")

String greeting = "Hello";
@Cleanup InputStream is = new ByteArrayInputStream(greeting.getBytes());
@Cleanup OutputStream os = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
 
while (true) {
    int val = is.read();
    if (val == -1) {
        break;
    }
    os.write(val);
} 

System.out.println(os.toString());

// don't need to call close

And your InputStream and OutputStream are closed. To prove that @Cleanup is working, let’s see a simple example below

public class CleanupWork {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        {
            @Cleanup MustBeClosedService service = new MustBeClosedService();
            System.out.println("Hello service");
        }
        System.out.println("Ended");
    }
}
 
class MustBeClosedService implements AutoCloseable {
    @Override
    public void close() {
        System.out.println("MustBeClosedService closed");
    }
}

Output:

>> Hello service
>> MustBeClosedService closed
>> Ended

Because MustBeClosedService has close() method so @Cleanup will call close after the scope

[4] Constructors

@NoArgsConstructor

Have you ever write a no argument constructor like this

public class Car {
    public Car() {
        // do nothing here
    }
}

You can get rid of that constructor with

@NoArgsConstructor
public class Car() {
}

@RequiredArgsConstructor

If you have final fields in your class, you have to have a constructor for these fields

public class MyService {
    private final RepositoryA repoA;
    private final RepositoryB repoB;
 
    public MyService(RepositoryA repoA, RepositoryB repoB) {
        this.repoA = repoA;
        this.repoB = repoB;
    }
}

You can get rid of that constructor with

@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class MyService {
    private final RepositoryA repoA;
    private final RepositoryB repoB;
}

@AllArgsConstructor

When a class with many fields and you want to have a constructor for all these fields, you will write the code like this

public class Employee {
    private Long id;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
 
    public Employee(Long id, String firstName, String lastName) {
        this.id = id;
        this.firstName = firstName;
        this.lastName = lastName;
    }
}

You can get rid of that constructor with

@AllArgsConstructor
public class Employee {
    private Long id;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;

    // other fields can be added without generate a new all arguments constructor
}

And when you add new fields into this class, you don’t need to change your constructor anymore as Lombok did it for you

[5] Data

Have you ever feel bad about these useless getters and setters, toString, hashCode and, toString? It just returns things and set things. Moreover, the way we generate or create those things is very mechanical too.

public class Employee {
    private Long id;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
 
    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return "Employee{" +
                "id=" + id +
                ", firstName='" + firstName + '\'' +
                ", lastName='" + lastName + '\'' +
                '}';
    }
 
    @Override
    public boolean equals(Object o) {
        if (this == o) return true;
        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
        Employee employee = (Employee) o;
        return Objects.equals(id, employee.id) &&
                Objects.equals(firstName, employee.firstName) &&
                Objects.equals(lastName, employee.lastName);
    }
 
    @Override
    public int hashCode() {
        return Objects.hash(id, firstName, lastName);
    }
}

With Lombok, you can remove these from your code with one simple annotation @Data

@Data
public class EmployeeLombok {
    private Long id;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
}

And then all getters and setters, toString, equals, hashCode, required arguments constructors is auto-generated for you.

[6] Log

When you have a service class and you want to have logging for this class, you have to do this

class CustomerService {
    private static final Logger LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(CustomerService.class);
 
    public Customer createCustomer(CustomerDto dto) {
        Customer newCustomer = dto.toCustomer();
 
        // validate and create a customer
 
        LOG.info("Customer created {}", newCustomer);
        return newCustomer;
    }
}

So with Lombok, you don’t need to initialize the logger anymore

@Slf4j
class CustomerService {
    public Customer createCustomer(CustomerDto dto) {
        Customer newCustomer = dto.toCustomer();
 
        // validate and create a customer
 
        log.info("Customer created {}", newCustomer);
        return newCustomer;
    }
}

So just declare @Slf4J or @Log on the class and you can use the log

Others

You can see all the examples at Git repo

And many more features, you can refer to it in the link Lombok

title: Manage files with Spring Boot and Minio (compatible with Amazon S3 APIs)
tags: api, java, spring, spring-boot, minio, storage
excerpt:
In this post, we will go steps by steps from how to create a spring boot project, setup Minio, to using it to store files.

You can find the sample code at the repo: https://gith...
content:
In this post, we will go steps by steps from how to create a spring boot project, setup Minio, to using it to store files.

You can find the sample code at the repo: https://github.com/dungvokms/demo-minio

Table of contents

  • Table of contents
  • What is Minio?
    • Example 1: Create a minio client
    • Example 2: Create a AWS S3 client
  • Install Minio
  • Create a Spring Boot project
  • Minio dependency
  • Create the project structure
    • Let’s edit the application.properties file
    • AppConfig
    • FileApi
    • Upload Api
    • Download Api
  • Run the code
    • Upload file
    • Download the uploaded file
  • Conclusion

What is Minio?

Minio is an object storage server released under Apache License v2.0. it is compatible with Amazon S3 cloud storage service. It is best suited for storing unstructured data such as photos, videos, log files, backups and container / VM images. Size of an object can range from a few KBs to a maximum of 5TB.

For more information: https://docs.minio.io

Example 1: Create a minio client

MinioClient minioClient = new MinioClient("https://play.minio.io:9000", "Q3AM3UQ867SPQQA43P2F", "zuf+tfteSlswRu7BJ86wekitnifILbZam1KYY3TG");

Example 2: Create a AWS S3 client

MinioClient s3Client = new MinioClient("https://s3.amazonaws.com", "YOUR-ACCESSKEYID", "YOUR-SECRETACCESSKEY");

Minio provides an abstract API for working with server storage as well as AWS S3 storage.

Install Minio

You can setup Minio easily using Docker, Homebrew (for Mac), Window, etc. Please refer to this link for setting up: https://docs.minio.io/docs/minio-quickstart-guide

On MacOS, after installing Minio, you can start minio server by using: minio server <YOUR_PATH>

For example: minio server ./minio/

Once you have done you can access http://localhost:9000 (default port is 9000)

Create a Spring Boot project

We can create a spring boot project simply by using http://start.spring.io.

We only need web and lombok (Optional) (https://projectlombok.org) for now.

Lombok is a great library to reduce boilerplates in your code.

You can read more about Lombok at this post

For more information about building an application with Spring Boot: https://spring.io/guides/gs/spring-boot

And hit the button Generate project

Minio dependency

Open pom.xml file and add this dependency to <dependencies>

<dependency>
    <groupId>io.minio</groupId>
    <artifactId>minio</artifactId>
    <version>4.0.1</version>
</dependency>

Create the project structure

We will build simple APIs that support for uploading and downloading files so the first one we need is FileApi. We also need to configure the application storage host, access key, secret key as well.

File Description
FileApi will receive upload/download requests
AppConfig is for configuring Minio client
DemoMinioApplication is the entry point of a spring boot project
application.properties will contain the configuration of the application

When starting the Minio server it will provide you the accessKey and secretKey generated if you don’t set it.

Let’s edit the application.properties file

app.minio.host=http://localhost:9000

AppConfig

It’s now to configure Minio Client

@Configuration
public class AppConfig {
 
    @Value("${app.minio.host}")
    private String minioHost;
 
    @Value("${app.minio.accessKey}")
    private String minioAccessKey;
 
    @Value("${app.minio.secretKey}")
    private String minioSecretKey;
 
    @Bean
    public MinioClient minioClient() throws InvalidPortException, InvalidEndpointException {
        return new MinioClient(minioHost, minioAccessKey, minioSecretKey);
    }
 
    // getters
}

With this config, the MinioClient will be managed by Spring Container so we can easily inject it into other beans when we need.

FileApi will need MinioClient so we will inject it into the FileApi

@RequestMapping("/files")
public class FileApi {
    private final MinioClient minioClient;
 
    public FileApi(MinioClient minioClient) {
        this.minioClient = minioClient;
    }
 
    // uploading file API

}

When we have only a constructor we don’t need to use @Autowired. Spring will automatically inject dependencies for us.

Upload Api

@PostMapping("/{bucketName}")
public void uploadFile(@PathVariable(“bucketName") String bucketName,
                       @RequestParam(“objectName") String objectName,
                       @RequestParam("file") MultipartFile file) 
throws IOException, InvalidKeyException, NoSuchAlgorithmException, InsufficientDataException, 
       InvalidArgumentException, InternalException,  NoResponseException, 
       InvalidBucketNameException, XmlPullParserException, ErrorResponseException {
 
    if (!minioClient.bucketExists(bucketName)) {
        minioClient.makeBucket(bucketName);
    }

    minioClient.putObject(bucketName, objectName, file.getInputStream(), file.getContentType());
}

This API will create a bucket if it not exists and then it will put the file into a bucketName and assign a name to it through the parameter objectName

Download Api

@GetMapping("{bucketName}/**")
public ResponseEntity<Resource> downloadFile(@PathVariable("bucketName") String bucketName,                                             HttpServletRequest request)
        throws IOException, InvalidKeyException, NoSuchAlgorithmException, 
               InsufficientDataException, InvalidArgumentException, InternalException, 
               NoResponseException, InvalidBucketNameException, XmlPullParserException, 
               ErrorResponseException {
 
    String path = String.valueOf(request.getAttribute(HandlerMapping.PATH_WITHIN_HANDLER_MAPPING_ATTRIBUTE));
    String objectName = path.substring(path.indexOf(bucketName) + bucketName.length() + 1);
    InputStream objectStream = minioClient.getObject(bucketName, objectName);    
    String fileName = objectName.substring(objectName.lastIndexOf('/') + 1);
 
    return ResponseEntity.ok()
            .contentType(MediaType.IMAGE_JPEG)
            .header(HttpHeaders.CONTENT_DISPOSITION, "attachment; filename=" + fileName)
            .body(new InputStreamResource(objectStream));
}

The line

String path = String.valueOf(request.getAttribute(HandlerMapping.PATH_WITHIN_HANDLER_MAPPING_ATTRIBUTE));

will get the request path for example, /files/vnd/pic1 in this case, the object name is pic1 and bucket name is vnd

The next line will extract the object name from the request path

String objectName = path.substring(path.indexOf(bucketName) + bucketName.length() + 1);
